abstract: With Warner Chilcott’s $3.1 billion deal to buy Procter & Gamble’s drug business, JPMorgan’s former private equity arm is minting cash. It’s understandable if the bank’s shareholders felt a twinge of remorse, Breakingviews writes. But they have a bonanza of fees to salve the pain.
snippet: With Warner Chilcott’s $3.1 billion deal to buy Procter & Gamble’s drug business, JPMorgan’s former private equity arm is minting cash. It’s understandable if the bank’s shareholders felt a twinge of remorse, Breakingviews writes. But they have a ...
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan stopped doing big leveraged buyouts on its own five years ago, after its takeover of Warner Chilcott, a pharmaceutical company, annoyed big clients like TPG, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Blackstone Group, Breakingviews.com writes.

headline.main: JPMorgan Shareholders Should Be Comforted by Fees
